respStmt.resp: XML templates, digitization architecture, and automated inline tagging

sourceDesc.bibl: Barnum, Francis/Reed, E. Irene/Teeluk, Martha (n.d. [late 1970s]): [Stories in Barnum 1901, retranscribed and transliterated by Irene Reed and Martha Teeluk]. Ms., Alaska Native Language Archive, Elmer E. Rasmuson Library, Fairbanks, Alaska. Quot. p. 283.

projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly, or mediated by an interpreter, from an informant who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose subsistence at the time of recording was, or until recently had been, depending primarily on hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative absence of external cultural influences.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the p prefix are pointers to person elements in the personography.xml file.
URIs using the q prefix are Wikidata Q identifiers and refer to the respective entries on Wikidata.
Private URIs using the g prefix are pointers to the respective lemmas in the FFDB collection of glossaries.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occurring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) on a case to case basis, without general rule.

normalization.p: Omissions as well as supplementations by the original editor are set in brackets. In all other cases, parentheses in the original are retained.
Latin passages in the original (usually to mask language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation has been removed. All other hyphenation has been retained.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. No effort was made to mark up passages in quotation marks as, for example, q, quote, said, cit, or soCalled.

interpretation.p: Animals, plants, colors, characters, and place names were automatically tagged using a semantic tagger based on WordNet and self-provided word lists, and were subsequently checked manually. They are tagged with animal, plant, color, persName, and placeName, respectively.

body.p:
And so thentōăthlū-hŏk-hwī, 'well, then', or 'so then'. (The usual preface to all stories.) [Inserted from Barnum 1901, p. 289.] - these two - it was two poor old women - they were both living [there] - and then - while they were both living there - by down there - river's sharp bend - on the other side of it - they remained - and then they saw - they [dual] heard - someone singing - and then - river's sharp bend - beyond it - they were both terrified - they packed up - their little effects - they embarked - into their poor old "aŋyak" [open boat] - then - things - their two small droppings - their little trail - their little woodpile - their water path - they effaced it - their household effects - all of them - after [their things] they were all ready [when they were done] - all right - their poor boat - they launched it - they launched all right - and loaded it - with their old [clothing, bedding, etc.] - like that - the thing down below there - it was approaching nearer all this time - they were in a panic - they were terrified - then - the elder one - she embarked - [and] embarking - her own friend [the other one] - she told her to embark - and then - her leg - the other - just [in the boat] - and then as she had it in [the boat] - she said - Oh - my poor little old needle case - I have forgotten - where I put it - Hold on!/Wait a minute - old woman - let me run and get it [them] - Wait for me - I will hurry - I will not delay - She finished? - she went - trying to run fast [but could not]
- because she was a very old woman - on account of her weakness - their little old house - she entered - going in slowly - something [anything] - she didn't see - because she didn't see it - again - she went back down - and then - to her poor old woman - she said - Look here - my needle case [past] which I had - is lost - and then - she told her to embark - her leg - once more - when she put it - in the boat - like this - water - down there - she looked - stickleback - that one - which was swimming along up - then - [and] singing - Oh, you good for nothing - up there - so it was he then who has been causing us terror - and then - with her own oar - she jabbed it - the thing which was scaring them - she got it up - to place on a flat surface [so that it can be readily chopped] - they two chopped it up - they cut it up - all right - after having been all chopped up - into the water - they threw it - all right - and after that was done - again -their little old place - they both returned - into their poor little old house - they went in - all right - and after their entrance - they both remained there.
